UBS:

BE11:15am

In one of the most unpredictable votes in House of Commons for
some time, and no doubt there have been many already this year,Boris Johnson's gamble to present MPs with his revised deal without
the support of the Northern Irish DUP has not paid off.

The vote on the deal didn't even surface as MPs by a majority of
322 against 306 passed an amendment that effectively postponed
the final decision on his deal. The law (Benn Act) states that the
prime minister has to request an extension of the Brexit deadline
to 31 January 2020. He has, on many occasions, suggested he will
not comply with this request. Despite his pronouncements, as we
expected, such a request has been made.

What comes next remains uncertain. We do not expect the EU to
reject the request for an extension but they may sit on the decision
for a few days to see if there is another chance to secure ratification
of the deal in the UK. They may also come back with a counter
proposal for a short, longer, or 'flextension' offer that MPs will have
to debate and approve.

BE11:15am

Parliament has on many occasions failed to find a consensus on the

way to progress Brexit. However, this isn’t the end of the road for

this deal. The prime minister will now attempt to pass further Brexit

legislation in order to secure a departure by 31 October. Success

here remains uncertain. The government has no majority and is

struggling to pass any legislation. As we write it still seems that a

general election, which we expect to happen before the end of this

year, will occur before UK decides which Brexit path to follow.

Following the large moves in sterling over the last week it is likely

we see further volatility in the days ahead as the next phase of Brexit

unfolds and the markets assess the prospects of a general election.

For the time being we retain our overweight position in sterling

versus the US dollar in our FX strategy. Parliament's rejection of a

deal may see the pound giving back some of its recent gains, but

as investors assess the prospect of a General Election, we expect

GBPUSD to settle in the 1.26 to 1.32 range. The coming days will

be important for assessing upside potential for the sterling beyond

that range.

casapinos Canaccord on "overvaluation plse?
11:15 am
BE11:16am

We expect the EU to accept this extension rather than face a no-deal,

although their decision may not be immediate. The prime minister will

press ahead with efforts to pass Brexit legislation to ensure a 31 October

departure. If he succeeds or fails, we expect to see a general election

before the end of the year. Parliament's rejection of a deal at the weekend

may see the pound giving back some of its recent gains, but as investors

assess the prospect of a general election, we expect GBPUSD to settle in

the 1.26 to 1.32 range.

• If the deal eventually passes, we would expect GBPUSD to rally to 1.35.

Beyond those levels, we think, sterling would struggle to rise as concerns

about the long-term trade relationship will come into focus. Moreover,

the UK economy does not look to be performing particularly better than

its peers at present.

• The risks of a no-deal Brexit at the end of October, or in the next six

months, are lower than they have been for many months. Following

Johnson's success in agreeing a new deal with the EU, we expect him to

enter the next election campaigning to leave with this deal rather than

no-deal. The no-deal scenario would have hurt GBPUSD, pulling it down

toward 1.12, in our view.

For the time being, we retain our overweight position in sterling versus the

US dollar in our FX strategy. The size of the market reaction in the last few

days indicates that positioning was, and probably still is, relatively short in

sterling, which bears out the latest International Money Market data. Hence,

strong upward moves could easily still be triggered, which favors retaining

an overweight position in sterling.

Berenberg ....

Bluesky21 Sorry IK
BE11:20am

Two reasons why the chance of an orderly Brexit has increased: 1) Johnson has already succeeded where his
predecessor Theresa May failed. The Eurosceptic wing of his party is now backing a deal for an orderly Brexit. With
322 to 306, the Saturday vote was already close. 2) This vote closed the last legal loophole that might have led to a hard
Brexit on 31 October. Some of those rebel Conservatives, independents and pro-Brexit Labour members of parliament
who did not vote for Johnson on Saturday because they do not trust him may now be ready to support the new Brexit
deal. Their priority is to rule out a hard Brexit, not to prevent an orderly Brexit. As a result, Johnson probably now has
the numbers to pass his deal. We thus raise the chance of an orderly Brexit from 35% to 75%, with a 60% probability
that the UK parliament will accept the new Brexit deal before 31 October.
• Hard Brexit risk down: We see a 40% risk that the UK parliament will not ratify Johnson’s Brexit deal before 31
October. This could lead to a longer Brexit extension with snap elections and/or a new referendum. Even in the case of
new elections, the risk of a hard Brexit would now be small. As the whole of the Conservative Party is now firmly
behind Johnson’s deal, no major party in parliament now wants or threatens to go for a hard Brexit. In case of a
snap election, Johnson would likely campaign and win a majority with his new deal, rather than on a hard Brexit ticket
as seemed possible before. Centre and centre-right moderate voters could support the Conservatives without fearing it
would lead to a hard Brexit. This is the key result of Johnson’s deal with the EU last week. We thus reduce the risk of
a hard Brexit from 35% to 10%. The residual risk could come into play if a) a surprise surge in support for Nigel
Farage’s Brexit Party before or in an election were to force Johnson to disavow his own deal; or b) if the UK and EU
fail to strike a deal on their future economic relations by the end of the transition period.

tadam My friend's father was Theresa May's first boss at the BoE. I guess it would be cheap to gossip, so I will not.
BE11:20am

Probability of no Brexit down: The one route to a reversal of Brexit – the “rebel alliance” of MPs who wanted to stop a
hard Brexit unites to back a second referendum – is partly closed off now that most Conservative rebels are ready to
vote for Johnson’s deal. Furthermore, in a second referendum, Johnson’s deal would probably stand a better chance of
beating “remain” than May’s old deal or a hard Brexit. We cut the probability of no Brexit to 15% from 30%.
• EU reaction – keep calm and carry on: The EU27 wants to avoid a hard Brexit, and, as its second priority, end the
Brexit mess as fast as possible. In response to Johnson’s “unsigned” extension request, the EU will probably wait
until shortly before 31 October to see whether the UK still passes the deal. If so, the EU would likely grant a short
technical extension if required to complete ratification proceedings in the UK and EU parliaments. Otherwise, the
EU may grant a brief extension with a deadline for the UK to propose a clear way forward before the EU may decide
whether it should offer a long extension to accommodate new UK elections and/or a new UK referendum.

BE11:29am

There is a both a sense of deja vu but also a concern that someone didn’t get the memo
about the Micro Focus period end weighting to its revenue line. We think that sensible
buyers will await news that Micro Focus has achieved FY results before launching a bid
either for part or for all of the company. We would expect a statement in late November.
A bidder is likely to aim for the upper end of the usual bid premium to the undisturbed
price – we suspect c35- 40%. A miss on the numbers would put MCRO share price under
pressure (dah) so hence we expect a bid when there is greater operational clarity. Bidders
could come from trade and PE, a bid could be for part (Arcsight and Fortify are already
names in the frame, we would add Vertica) or for the entire company. Oh and don’t say
that Micro Focus is too big to be acquired – remember Computer Associates US$18.9bn
cash purchase by Broadcom last year. We would anticipate a contested bid. We maintain
our Buy.

Bluesky21 Is Micro Focus not an example of how management can make money from a company's size and profitability ... but size definitely counts more and is easier?

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Micro Focus' business is focused on acquiring and managing mature infrastructure software assets and the business is not seeking growth, but rather to manage and optimize the revenue decline of the assets it owns. The business has been challenged with stabilizing the revenue declines post the acquisition of HPE's software portfolio. We believe that the business could be of interest to other mature infrastructure software vendors or to financial sponsors, which would be consistent with the company's strategic review and goal of maximizing shareholder returns.

Precedent Transactions. We note precedent transactions where BMC Software was taken private in 2013 for about 5.8x EV/LTM recurring rev. and CA was acquired by Broadcom in 2018 for about 5.2x EV/LTM recurring rev. Micro Focus trades at approx. 3.9x EV/LTM recurring revenue, however, as we noted, the business is ex-growth. We calculated the intrinsic value of the business to be 4.2x recurring revenue (assuming a 5% revenue decline into perpetuity), compared to 6.2x (post-2018 U.S. tax reform) for a no-growth on-premise business.

BE11:42am

Hitherto M&A interest in Capco has focused on Earls Court, with an ongoing
process with a number of interested parties aiming to acquire the scheme
ahead of its proposed demerger. As announced by the company in late
September, bids are at “a range of discounts to the balance sheet value”.
 We have previously talked about an independent Covent Garden (1.2m sq ft
of prime Central London real estate valued at £2.6bn) being a prized asset,
particularly for long-term global capital pools. As a read across, peer
Shaftesbury (Hold, TP 900p) trades at a 4% discount to NAV but has a share
register that we believe hinders corporate activity.
 The sensitivity table below sets out the upside to the current share price based
on a range of discounts/premiums to both Covent Garden and Earls Court.
Although no indication of pricing has been made, on an assumption of at least
book value for Covent Garden and a c40% discount to gross asset value for
Earls Court then there is near 20% upside.
 This equates to c300p per share, against the June NAV per share of 315p. But,
as the table shows, a more optimistic valuation of Covent Garden could have a
material impact on the potential upside.

Just Eat has just released its Q3 trading update. Key metrics are below expectations with group revenue
growth of 25% versus JPMe +30% and group order growth 16% (JPMe +26%). Most importantly, UK orders
increased by 8% to 33m after 11% in Q2 (JPMe +11% in Q3) and the company previously pointing to “a
meaningful improvement in H219”. Weak order growth had been slightly mitigated by a rising share in (high
commission but low margin) delivery orders, leading to a lower miss on revenues. We have anticipated slowing
growth in the UK in Q3 in our recent detailed note on UK takeaway here and, while the company still maintains
FY guidance (see below), we expect consensus to settle at the lower end of the range.

Credit Suisse:

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Order Growth soft – UK order growth of +8% (vs CSe +13%) was largely driven by
two factors: 1) broadly softer consumer spending backdrop, which we believe is affecting
the sector as a whole, and that Just Eat has not lost market share; and 2) Changing
consumer preferences as the shift towards healthy eating continues, impacting Just Eat’s
Marketplace business. We expect both these trends to continue into 4Q19. Despite the
soft UK order growth number, we believe the buy-side had broadly, already come down to
single-digit growth on the back of credit card transaction data.
■ Non-UK robust – Non-UK order growth of +26% (vs CSe +23%) was driven by: 1)
Continued strong double-digit order growth in Canada where we believe that despite
competitive dynamics, the Group’s revenue and profitability is developing well; 2) Notable
recovery in ANZ, where the Group delivered “double digit-order growth” ahead of our
estimates of +8%, this is largely driven by the roll-out of delivery logistics in the region; and
3) Ongoing strong performance in Europe, where the regions that showed strength in
1H19, notably Italy and Switzerland, continue to do so.
■ FY19 Guidance re-iterated – The Group has reconfirmed its guidance for FY19 revenue
in the range of £1.0-1.1bn (CSe: £1.05bn) and uEBITDA in the range of £185-205mn

BE12:04pm

CSe: £191mn) (both excluding Brazil and Mexico). Just Eat’s share of its Latin American
operations (Brazil and Mexico) are also expected to report an FY19 uEBITDA loss in the
range of £80-100mn (CSe: £83mn), as previously stated.
■ No update on potential Just Eat / Takeaway merger – We receive no additional
updates in today’s release, with the shareholder circular still expected to be published at
the end of October, the General meeting to be held in December and pending shareholder
approval, the transaction expected to be completed around year end. As of Friday 18th
October close, Just Eat was trading +1% ahead of the bid premium.
■ Valuation – Just Eat trades at 3.1x FY20e EV/Sales vs Delivery Hero on 3.6x and
Takeaway.com on 8.2x. We continue to believe that the combination of Just Eat and
TKWY offers Just Eat the opportunity to unlock the value of its assets, however do flag
that with it trading at only +1% ahead of the bid premium (vs +7% when the deal was first
announced), the implied likelihood of a counter-bid is increasingly diminishing.
